title: AB 1721
content: The State of California enacts the following. The Legislature acknowledges the need to produce 11,900,000 degrees and credentials by 2025, with a projected gap of 2,400,000. California's community colleges are vital in closing this gap, especially for low-income students. Financial aid programs like the Cal Grant and BOG Fee Waiver are crucial in supporting students' enrollment and success in college. California invests in need-based financial aid for college students through the Cal Grant Program and the BOG Fee Waiver Program. The Cal Grant Program awards over $2 billion annually, making it the largest state grant program in the nation. The BOG Fee Waiver Program provides free tuition to almost half of all California Community College students. However, access grants are insufficient to cover non-tuition costs, leaving many low-income students without support. Community college students in California are often first-generation, immigrants, or financially needy. California's community college students, often first-generation, immigrants, or financially needy, face affordability challenges due to non-tuition costs. To address this, increasing grant aid for non-tuition expenses is crucial. The Legislature aims to renew California's commitment to college affordability by expanding the Cal Grant Program to support students in career technical education programs. The Legislature aims to expand the Cal Grant Program to support students in career technical education programs by providing outreach and education on financial aid availability. The Competitive Cal Grant A and B award program will be established for eligible students, with awards not being entitlements. Selection of students will be based on specified criteria. Starting from the 2016-17 academic year, up to 34,000 Cal Grant A and B awards will be granted annually on a competitive basis. 15,000 awards are available to all students meeting financial and academic requirements, with a March 2 deadline for baccalaureate degree institutions and a choice of March 2 or September 2 deadline for California community college students. Additionally, 19,000 awards are reserved for California community college students with a September 2 application deadline. Starting from the 2016-17 academic year, up to 34,000 Cal Grant A and B awards will be granted annually on a competitive basis. 15,000 awards are available to all students meeting financial and academic requirements, with a March 2 deadline for baccalaureate degree institutions and a choice of March 2 or September 2 deadline for California community college students. Additionally, 19,000 awards are reserved for California community college students with a September 2 application deadline. Effective from the fall term of the 2017-18 academic year, students enrolled in occupational or technical training courses at a California community college will be eligible for Cal Grant B awards. If any awards are not distributed initially, the commission will allocate them based on financial need and academic merit, up to a total of 34,000 awards annually. The commission will establish selection criteria for Cal Grant A and B awards, giving special consideration to disadvantaged students. Additional consideration will be given to students reestablishing their grade point averages and those who did not receive awards previously. All eligible students can compete for an award. Section 69439 of the Education Code is amended. All eligible students meeting requirements can compete for an award under Section 69439 of the Education Code, which defines terms like "career pathway" and "long-term unemployed." Cal Grant C awards are for occupational or technical training after secondary school, lasting at least four months. The number of awards remains the same each year as in 2015-16, with funding determined annually. Criteria for selecting recipients include family income, household status, and special consideration for disadvantaged or economically challenged applicants. The Cal Grant C award recipients are eligible for renewal until they finish their occupational or technical training. The criteria for selection include family income, household status, and employment status, with a focus on long-term unemployed applicants. Grants are limited to two calendar years. Cal Grant C awards can be used for tuition, fees, training-related costs, and living expenses. The commission considers the student's financial means and available state and federal programs when determining award amounts. The commission collaborates with state and federal agencies to identify areas of occupational training eligible for Cal Grant C awards. The commission regularly reviews and updates occupational and technical training areas every five years. By January 1, 2016, priority areas for training will be updated. Priority for Cal Grant C awards is given to students in high-demand occupational fields with good job prospects and economic security. At least one of the criteria must be met for priority consideration. The commission determines occupational or technical training areas in consultation with relevant departments and organizations, using labor market projections. They publish and update a list of these areas on their website as needed. The commission prioritizes Cal Grant C award applicants for programs with high graduation rates and job placement data. They collaborate with various agencies to publicize the grant program to long-term unemployed individuals. The commission collaborates with agencies to inform Cal Grant C recipients about job search services. The Legislative Analyst's Office must report on program outcomes biennially. The Legislative Analyst's Office reports biennially on Cal Grant C recipients, including demographics, training program categories, selection priority, job placement success, and comparison of program enrollment before and after policy implementation.
